definition:
An *annulus* is the region bounded between two (usually concentric)
circles.

An *open annulus* is a domain in the complex plane of the form
$$A = A_w(r,R) = \{z \in {\mathbb{C}}: r < |z-w| < R\},$$ where $w$ is
an arbitrary complex number, and $r$ and $R$ are real numbers with
$0 < r < R$. Such a set is often called an *annular region*.

It should be noted that the annulus usually refers to an open annulus.

More generally, one can allow $r = 0$ or $R = \infty$. (This makes sense
for the purposes of the bound on $|z-w|$ above.) This would make an
annulus include the cases of a punctured disc, and some unbounded
domains.

Analogously, a *closed annulus* is a set of the form
$${\overline{A}} = {\overline{A}}_w(r,R) = \{z \in {\mathbb{C}}: r \leq |z-w| \leq R\},$$
where $w \in {\mathbb{C}}$, and $r$ and $R$ are real numbers with
$0 < r < R$.

One can show that two annuli $D_w(r,R)$ and $D_{w'}(r',R')$ are
conformally equivalent if and only if $R/r = R'/r'$. More generally, the
complement of any closed disk in an open disk is conformally equivalent
to precisely one annulus of the form $D_0(r,1)$.
